conbody.p: A matrix is a way to display grouped data and summary information on two axis (x-axis, y-axis) where each axis is linked to a grouping criteria; i.e., dataset attribute. Values in matrix cells display aggregate values scoped to the intersection of the row and column groups to which the cell belongs.

A matrix, therefore, has a dynamic number of rows and columns, whereas a table has a fixed number of columns, known at design time. A matrix is displayed in a frame and cannot be paginated. Thus, the number of possible values for each group criteria used on axis must be limited.
Rows and columns can be formatted to highlight the data you want to emphasize. Totals of cell values can be displayed or hidden for row, column, and the entire matrix.
Additional columns can extend the matrix with other aggregated data for each row.
